        "id": "87305633",
        "author": "a9355131-2b59-5518-ad76-4e4c3a607a3e",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 1683,
        "content": "This is what we want Sega/Atlus, more Persona and other games ports on PC please.\n\nThe gameplay is excellent and at the start I thought it was just a total cash grab due to the price but this is a genuine Persona game even with the involment of Koei Tecmo in this game. This is actually what a non Turn-role Persona game would be like. It is more of a Persona game than a Dynasty Warrior clone.\n\nThe game takes place after the event of Persona 5 during the summer vacation as the Phantom Thieves yet again find theirselves in another quest to change hearts.\n\nGameplay; Smooth 60fps locked. No drops. it is to be noted that some cutscenes are running at 30fps but there isnt many of them. The key bindings isn't that bad and it is easy to learn them and can be changed if you need to. The combat is very fast paced and the mechanics are well implemented. I'd give it a 9/10.\n\nGraphics: They are not bad but also not superb due to something that looks like a lack of strong AA but overall they are fine. 7.5/10\n\nSpecs needed: This game is not very demanding and even 700 series GTX cards can handle it fine as long as you tune the settings a bit. 8/10.\n\nMusic: Now this is the part that is actually an absolute hit. If you do buy the digital deluxe edition you have access to battle ost from previous persona games ranging from Persona revelation up to Persona 5 Strikers. The sound quality in Persona games is alway top notch and this one delivers as well. 9.5/10.\n\nFinal thoughts: Should you buy it? I would say wait for sales because, the standard version really doesn't shine like the digital deluxe edition with all its bonuses. However, for long time persona fans, I doubt this will be too much of a concern to them. I should also mention that , even if you did not play Persona 5 this is not an issue as this game seems to be a total different setting. Also thanks to Koei Tecmo for making this game with Atlus.\n\nMy overall score: 8.5/10.",
        "comments": 0,
        "source": "steam",
        "helpful": 3,
        "funny": 0,
        "recommended": true,
        "franchise": "Persona",
        "gameName": "Persona 5 Strikers"
    },
    {
        "id": "87305609",
        "author": "27ff1017-5ecc-5051-ab5f-eed9da78a9b3",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 3811,
        "content": "With this game being in a somewhat unique situation, there's three main areas I want to address in this review: playing this game without playing Persona 5, the state of the PC port, and the game itself. \n\nPC Port up first! The port is very simplistic unfortunately. No ultrawide support, capped at 60fps, and limited settings to adjust (there is an internal resolution scaler though, which can go up to 2.0). The port runs well though - I have an 8700k and a 3080, and I've had basically a locked 60fps at 1440p with all settings maxed and the scaler set to 2.0 (and I haven't hit any bugs yet, but I've only played for a few hours). I imagine that this game will be able to run on a very wide variety of PCs, which is good. One minor complaint I do have however is that the UI is pretty big, and there's no option to re-size it. It's not too much of an issue when running around the world, but during battle it very much gets in the way. \n\nWhat's not good is that you really shouldn't play this game if you haven't played Persona 5 (And like many, I am absolutely baffled that they haven't brought P5 to PC yet. Especially with this game being a direct sequel). Not only will you spoil some great P5 moments for yourself, but this game doesn't really do anything to hold your hand story-wise. It does some very baseline \"story setup\" in regards to the overall world and lore, but it very much assumes that you've played Persona 5 (or are at least very familiar with it and the characters). So if you haven't played, chances are that you'll have no idea what on earth is happening or who any of these characters are. \n\nAs for the game itself, so far I'm enjoying it! I'm not completely sold on the combat yet (which I'll get to a bit later), but the game feels like a legitimate Persona 5 sequel. I don't know how much of a hand that Atlus had in development and how much was Omega Force, but this game feels right at home with Persona 5 in terms of the writing and character interactions. As always, the voice actors have brought their A-game (I'm playing with English VO) and they do just as great of a job as in P5. Omega Force has introduced a few new characters as well, and they all feel like they just fit right in. I'm sure you'll have heard about Sophia by the time you play, and yes - she is as precious as everyone says she is. \n\nHowever, don't go in expecting a full-blooded Persona game. As far as I'm aware, there are no confidant levels, no school, no social stats to level up, etc. While this absolutely feels like a proper sequel in terms of tone and design, just remember that it's a Persona-themed hack and slash game, and not an actual Persona game proper. And with that, we come to the combat! Which is hard to give a full opinion on because I've only played the game for a few hours but I'm going to do my best to give my thoughts as I have them. \n\nConceptually, I love combat (also as a note, I'm playing with a PS4 controller so I'll be referring to it for the button layout). Each character has standard attacks that you'll button mash with the Square button, a special attack (that can be weaved into combos) that's mapped to Triangle, and their persona which is summoned by holding down R1. Hitting Triangle will do different things depending on when it's used in a combo. Using Triangle does something different than if hitting it after hitting Square 2 times, or 3, or 4 (each one presents a different ability). While each character performs combos in the same way (each character has a Square + Triangle combo, a Square + Square + Triangle combo, etc) they do different things for each character, and it can be a bit overwhelming to keep it all straight. However, I imagine that this will naturally dissipate as the game is played for longer. \n\nWhen holding down R1 to summon your persona, battle freezes - this lets you choose your persona/ability and choose the area to deploy it at your leisure. You can switch between any party member at any time if they're in your current party (you're still limited to 4 party members, but these party members can be switched when not in combat), and you can even run around as your chosen party member while in the Metaverse, which I really like. When a typical battle starts, you'll run into one of 3 enemy types: general blade fodder, personas, and \"boss\" personas. The blade fodder are just faceless enemies that you can hack and slack your way through, and don't present any challenge at all. Personas are the personas that we know and love from P5, and this is where you'll want to use the correct party member/persona ability to target their affinities. \"Boss\" personas (I put boss in quotes because it's not an actual boss, they're just tougher versions of the normal personas) can take multiple affinity hits before getting knocked down, and are generally tougher to kill/do more damage. \n\nThere's a lot more to combat, but that's the elevator pitch. Why am I hesitant on it? Because honestly, at times it feels very frantic and unfocused. As mentioned at the beginning, the battle UI takes up way too much of your screen. It's at least 1/4, if not 1/3 of your screen real estate. Add to that all of your party members mashing their standard attack and sending off persona abilities, plus the enemies are doing the same, it results in so much visual overload that I can barely keep track of what's going on. The game recommends trying to use different party members to chain together combos and such, but I can barely keep track of what's going on - there's no way I'll be able to chain things together efficiently. It's also difficult to keep track of your own health - the in-game characters will sound off voice dialogue to let you know that your health is getting low, but sometimes you miss it with the amount of stuff happening on screen and it all just feels a little hectic. \n\nAll that being said, I'm still enjoying the game thoroughly. This is about as close to a \"Persona 5 2\" as we'll ever get, and it's a damn fine follow up. When you're only facing a few enemies and can actually pull off the combos that the game wants you to, it's very satisfying. I'm hoping that my problems with the combat will go away as I get more used to it, but only time will tell there (I'll most likely update this review after finishing the game). If you love this world and these characters, I highly recommend playing this game.",

If you want to fully enjoy this game and cannot get your hands on P5/P5R, a good place to start is to watch the Animated series [url=https://p5ausa.com/]Persona 5 The Animation[/url]. Although the quality of the animation isn't the highest, it covers all the important stories and can get enough background information to not get lost playing this game.\n\nAs for the game itself, so far so good. Need to play more to see if this game can match or even beat P5.\n\n\u81ea\u5e26\u4e2d\u6587\uff0c\u800c\u4e14\u4f4e\u4ef7\u533a\u6bd4\u6e2f\u670d\u6253\u6298\u8fd8\u8981\u4fbf\u5b9c\uff0c\u597d\u8bc4\uff01\n\n[Updated after 10 hrs playtime]\nAfter finishing the first part of the story, I have a general grasp on how the game is played and can say more on the performance and gameplay itself.\nThere are some flaws to the game, including relatively longer load time comparing to other games and to playing it on PS5 (I am running this game also on a high-performance SSD). Especially when I load up the game, it usually takes me 10 to 15 seconds to actually be able to play the game. I am not sure the problem can be fixed, and it is rather minor problem, but this will be frustrating after more hours of playtime, which I know I will be having. Another thing that stands out to me is that although I am playing this game on a controller, the character can only move along the 8 axis using the left stick. This is definitely bad porting, and I haven't experienced anything like this on other ported games like Yakuza series or Atlus' own Persona 4 Golden.\n\nGameplay is solid so far, but also missing out on a lot of thing that really made persona series stands out from other JRPG games - daily interactions. While the game still using the calendar system like its predecessors, there are less layer to that because you are free to spend however long time you want in one day and do whatever you want. Being able to go and return palace (jails) freely without worrying about time passing is more player-friendly, but it feels like cheating to just freely go in and out to recover your hp and sp.\nUp till this point of the game, I haven't had any side stories and bonding time with other characters. The city has much less things to explore and places to go. Although it seems like we got to visit more cities, so that might still be fun.\nI guess I just miss the time to spend with all my [spoiler]waifus[/spoiler]friends and school life.\nThe fighting is fun, and the way the incorporate the old persona system to this musou type game is very interesting.\n\nA solid 8/10 so far. Definitely recommend if you have played Persona 5 before, and worth to play if you haven't and don't mind missing out on some stories or spend time watching the anime series",

        "author": "aa4749b5-3c9e-55da-8422-d9f8ec87ad52",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 2655,
        "content": "ive had a lot of fun so far!! the persona battle elements keep it from being like other hack and slash type games, so if you're not a fan of those this might still be worth a try. the story is a direct sequel to persona 5 and it doesn't offer much explanation so definitely play that before picking this up! ive had minor issues with crashing and a few animations are a little wonky, but otherwise its a very good game - just be sure to save often :) here's a few fyis for people playing:\n\nthe preset keyboard controls are a nightmare. i highly recommend using a controller, but if you really don't want to then be sure to go into config and reset them to whatever works for you. once you get past the main menu you have to play through the entire prologue before getting the chance to do it again so this is super important if you dont want to be reaching over to press H and N constantly! \n\nyou can leave the metaverse at any checkpoint, with no time penalty. if you're low on sp just leave and immediately come back, there's no reason not to. you should also be using healing skills more often than items, because there's essentially an infinite supply of sp. save your healing items for battles.\n\nsimilar to the last game, its best that everyone stays alive, even if they're at 1 hp. losing a party member means losing a quarter of total damage. however, in this game, joker dying isnt an instant game over. to lose, *every* party member has to die, not just the protag. if the character you're playing is low on health, switch to another. the ai will automatically keep them away from danger (mostly) and you can get back to fighting.\n\nyou start the game with joker, then unlock everybody else at once so it can be kind of overwhelming. every character is fairly well balanced so just play whoever you like most. i use ann and yusuke often because they're fast and do quick damage, but if you prefer more hard hitting characters ryuji and haru are a good choice. sophie and makoto are both a moderate between those. you unlock 'arts' while playing a character, which gives them new moves and other helpful stuff. once you've unlocked all of a character's arts, its good to switch to a new one so that you can have a party thats all boosted!\n\nin the game, confidants are replaced by a bond level. when your bond levels up you get bond points, which you can use to get upgrades. i highly recommend 'strength boost', which increases everyone's physical attack damage (essentially 90% of the damage you'll be doing), as well as ambusher and oracle recovery, which both restore hp after battles.\n\nfusion accidents happen CONSTANTLY, i dont know if its just my bad luck or something but it feels like 1 out of every 5 is an accident, so don't get too attached to whatever you're fusing.\n\nanyways its a really fun game!!!!! play it!!!!!!!!!!!",

The amount of actual story in this game is questionable at best. With the removal of confidants and making dialogue scenes more and more scarce there is no actual character development.\n\nThe game is also bugged. Even on a good rig the game still runs slowly and at one point the \ngame would soft lock you from continuing. To remedy this I had to try multiple methods that were convoluted just to progress.         "id": "87299741",
        "author": "b035481c-1119-5293-8ef0-567e6bbf40d1",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 4374,
        "content": "No Kasumi, but the new characters Sophia and Zenkichi are pretty cool. Dialogue is funny, but has its cringe moments, so classic Persona.\n\nHow turn-based Persona mechanics would translate to the Warriors style gameplay was what I was most interested in when I heard about Scramble, and having put a good amount of time into Strikers, I can say that it flows together near seamlessly. There's a bit of a learning curve, I died a fair amount on the first few bosses, but once you get a feel for the flow of combat, you can string together some nasty combos. This made the second major boss feel like a cakewalk in comparison, not because it was easier in difficulty, but because I knew how to use my SP and movement more effectively. I'm near the end of the third \"dungeon\" and this pattern has continued. XP and money grinding is always available, and when the game says leaving the dungeon has no downside, it means there's literally no downside. Just wait like 1 minute for the cutscenes, then reenter to find all your SP refilled. This all makes it so that even if you suck like I did at first, you can still progress through brute force, though learning the mechanics is your best bet, as that one minute of Mementos' \"woahwoahwoahwoahwoahwoah\" cutscenes will get annoying.\n\nDefinitely a worthwhile pickup for fans of P5, and one of the best Warriors-style games I've played.",

    {
        "id": "87298372",
        "author": "f16c01ce-39f5-5b60-b82a-390363afa83e",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 4019,
        "content": "I beat the game not too long ago, and I have to say this:\n\nAs someone who played Persona 5 original and Royal prior to this, it is a step down story wise. That's not saying it's a bad story line, but it is rather similar and some parts are lifted from the original games. I'll put anything spoil related at the far bottom so if anyones not played, they can't see it. My pros and cons:\n\nPros:\n-The combat is FANTASTIC. Going into this, I had a hard time getting used to it, because I was used to the slower combat from Persona 5, but this... hits so hard, literally. The combat feels so heavy, and that in my personal opinion makes games like this great. \n-The dialogue is cheesy at times, but there are so many moments that I laughed my ass off due to comedic timing, and just Yusuke being Yusuke. There are many screenshots I hold dearly from this game of the dialogue. \n-The music is OUTSTANDING. I remember hearing River in the Desert for the first time in Persona 5, and I remember how badass it sounded. But they literally looked at the original soundtrack, took the best songs and said: \"Hey, let's make this more kickass\". Believe it or not, it's more kickass. Rivers in the Desert, Last Surprise and most importantly, Daredevil, the 3rd version of Life will Change if you will. These songs made this game SO good, because you felt the pressure, and high tension. I listen to these songs out of game, they're that good. Also Sophia's shop's theme SLAPS.\n-The art style is so good. The cities you visit feel like a snapshot from real life and pasted into this game with a hint of that really colorful Persona style. \n-The bosses are actually really good. Usually in a game like this, there are a lot of lackluster bosses and the mini bosses are easy and boring. But they did something really interesting with the Request system, where later in the game, you can get requests to beat the boss of the city again, beat really powerful shadows around the area, or just farm. Personally speaking, I liked the Warden system, which are essentially mini bosses before the main boss. They give you a feel for the \"villain\", and give them character, which makes a good antagonist. (Sapporo boss is a meme tho, it's honestly funny to play, but fun)\n-Showtimes and All-Out Attacks are AMAZING. The devs took the idea of All-Out Attacks from the original game and pumped it with CRACK. When you see the way it's used in Persona 5 and can find it a little confusing on how you implement it in this game, and I was there at the beginning, but they managed to make it incredibly smooth, which kind of ties into the combat part, but this is separated because there will never be a better feeling than having finishing a strong shadow off with Ryuji leading an All-Out Attack and finishing it with: \"S E E  Y A ! !\"\n-The fact that you can play as the other characters is so amazing. Ambushing enemies as Yusuke, him saying \"I shall expose you.\" in the most composed matter, man, you can't ask for better.\n-THE GAME DOESN'T END IF JOKER DIES!!\n-Level design is SUPERB. This does tie with the art style aspect, but I just have to shout out how good the Shibuya level looks and sounds. The music and levels work SO well. \n-The new characters are so good man, I can't express how much I love Zenkichi. The way he plays off the rest is so natural and hilarious. Sophia is adorable and we must protect her. \n-It is mandatory to bring up Ryuji saying the F word. (Fun fact, the F word is used twice in this entire game, once by Ryuji, and once by a flashback shadow)\n-They started using 3D cutscenes and they are amazing, please do that more often Atlus.\n\nCons:\n-The animation is a liiitle weird at times. My main issue with this is how lifeless everyone looks when they're chilling in the van or just in cutscenes. At times it was just funny how their blank expressions would never change when they would chant \"Yeah! Let's infiltrate this jail!\". \n-The story is a little strange. It is a typical JRPG at times and it reeeally shows. I'll continue my thoughts further down. \n-The music is a little loud when you first launch the game, and you can't change it if you start a new game after a while of cut scenes, which leads me into my next point:\n-There are a little too many cut scenes at times. It was clear that there were a lot of shortcuts taken with cut scenes and how they skip around. I know this is a nitpick, but with how good this game is, that's really what it comes to. \n-The combat *can* get repetitive, but if you really think about it, that's the same case with Persona 5, but this game is about 40 hours shorter than the original. \n-I did mention earlier that the dialogue is amazing, but there was some dialogue that made me cringe. But then again, it's a typical JRPG in that regard. They could have cut down on how many times they say ones name when that particular person is upset or expressing something. \n-I don't know if this is just me, but I had issues with crashing. There were many times in my play through that I would beat a boss, relieved, then mid cut scene, the game would freeze and then crash. \n-The limited supplied for cooking is frustrating, but I totally understand why they did that, because cooked items are *busted* if you save them for future battles. \n\nShould you play Persona 5 before this? Yes. \n\nIs it necessary? No, but it is highly recommended, due to a lot of references to the previous games (except Maruki, like what) \n\nIs this game worth the price? Yes. I know that's up for debate, but honestly, you can get a *lot* of hours in this game, which is what makes games worth their price. If I'm being honest, I could've spent up to 70-80 hours if I 100%ed it, but I every request except the Prison mails. \n\nIs Deluxe worth it? As someone who purchased the deluxe, I will say that it's not necessarily worth the extra $10, but it is nice to be able to change your battle music and see art for the game. \n\n10/10 Game. \n\n*SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT*\n\n\n\n\n\n-The story is verrrrry similar to Persona 5, in the sense that you fight a god, again. I kind of see why they did that, but it was rather recycled, due to EMMA looking extremely similar to the final boss from P5. Was it fun? Yes, the only reason really is the aspect of splitting everyone into three groups to finish EMMA off. I will give kudos to that, which is a good idea for a final boss. I will say this: The cut scene of everyone finishing off EMMA in an All-Out Attack, is SO good. Everyone got proper screen time, including Haru. \n-Sophia going with Ichinose is so wholesome, it made my heart feel good :)\n-Zenkichi catching Owada is so heartwarming :)",

        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 6634,
        "content": "10/10 game, now keep it up and bring the rest of the Persona franchise to PC.\n\n[h1]Gameplay[/h1]\n\nPersona 5 Strikers is a step in a brand new direction for the entire Persona franchise, yet entirely fits all of the knowledge we currently have on the series. Every single translation of a skill from the JRPG format to the Dynasty Warriors format makes complete sense. The combat system feels incredible and flows perfectly with the styles of all of the Phantom Thieves, each of the Thieves' fighting style perfectly matching their character. The game also encourages you to use all of the Phantom Thieves (and no spoilers, you should it helps later on), beyond just using them to hit weaknesses.  The game may feel difficult, as bosses can have an insane amount of health if you don't have maxed equipment or the best Personas, but remember that the game encourages you to spend a lot of time in the Jails and that unlike the original Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal: [b]You can re-enter a Jail as many times as you want on a single day, refreshing your HP/SP every single time.[/b]\n\n[h1]Story/Characters[/h1]\n\nThe story is entertaining, and the new characters are welcome additions to the Persona 5 cast. The new Phantom Thieves fit incredibly well with the others, and their additions to the cast prove that it's not just high school kids who can change reality. There's a good balance of comedy relief with serious plot points, and the game knows when to take itself in either direction. Without spoilers, the late-game stuff can get incredibly emotional if you're invested, and again fits with the rest of the series while trying something new. \n\n[h1]Voice Actors/Thank You[/h1]\n\nThe best part of this game is the English VA's. You can tell that every single one of them was having a blast in the recording studio, and became the Phantom Thieves [sttrike]more than any cringy fan on social media ever could[/strike]. It wasn't as obvious to me in Persona 5/Royal, but in this game it was clear that every single voice actor was having a blast and completely invested in their characters, which was something that couldn't necessarily be given during a first game in a series like P5/P5R. As the characters grew, so did the VA's and it really showed in this game. To the English Cast, thank you for an incredible performance, and can't wait for the next one.\n\n[h1]Conclusion[/h1]\n\nAll in all, wait for P5/P5R to come out on PC if you haven't played them already, or play it on PS4 since it's out there now. Persona 5 Strikers was an incredible experience that I can't wait to play over and over again to 100% and the point where I have every Persona completely maxed out. I'm incredibly happy to see that ATLUS doesn't need to make a JRPG to have an incredible entry into the Persona franchise.",

    {
        "id": "87296972",
        "author": "4243259a-b5d8-59cc-bc8f-e1444e2bd25c",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 693,
        "content": "The Phantom Thieves are back, just in a different way than fans of the series are used to. \n\nThey've been given the Musou treatment to resemble a dynasty warriors game, at least with combat. And the dungeons have also been simplified to match the new gameplay style, while retaining jokers ability to switch persona on the fly and some element of party management and group control / move selection in order to retain the persona series feeling, however has ripped away the confidant system to be replaced by \"bonds\", which are upgrade-able by the player at any point, each providing its own unique buff. \n\nThe game does try to introduce new ideas like this, however the concept is still the same as in previous games with antagonists becoming corrupted enough to create their own alternate reality. However there's a slight change here which allows the Jail Monarch to control people in the real world, forcing the Phantom Thieves to travel around Japan to stop them.\n\nThe story in Persona 5 Strikers isn\u2019t as compelling or thought provoking as its predecessors, yet the game is filled with fan service, and numerous references to the characters backstories and events from previous games, which for fans of the series is excellent and not forced, however for newcomers to the series will be just a tad confusing as none of them are explained. \n\nIt looks amazing retaining its slick punchy style and surreal colour schemes, each cutscene and special move have been choreographed carefully to capture each character's personality. In this regard Strikers still feels very much like a Persona game and hasn\u2019t lost any of its charm, with voice acting to match, it's hard to call this a spin-off, clearly time and effort was taken with this rather than just being a money grab. \n\nOverall, although it's shifted from its winning JRPG formula, the gameplay, narrative, story line and combat are all well worth playing through the 30 (ish) hour campaign for, however only for fans of the series, i'd generally say this is an awful entry point for new players, and to pick up p4 and p5 first.",

    {
        "id": "87294613",
        "author": "e32c4fe0-4cb6-5973-bbc1-79f33bf68bd5",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 3209,
        "content": "So I've seen a lot of great reviews, so this may just be a me issue but I need to mention it anyways because I love this game and want it to succeed as I have genuinely enjoyed it since fixing this issue on my own. \n\nThe control-scheme was very non-intuitive for the way they had it set up for people using mouse & keyboard. It doesn't play very smooth at all and I spent a pretty significant amount of time in the key-bindings menu trying to get things squared away. The issue was that there are so many commands, but the keyboard & mouse setup is designed as if you're just playing with keyboard, so the same buttons used to for left and right mouse are in the immediate area of WASD. This would be fine, if it didn't \"push\" other important commands to further locations from my hand on the keyboard, causing me to have to adjust my hand placement on the keyboard pretty regularly during fights until I changed the settings.\n\nThis isn't something that makes me regret getting the game, and I absolutely LOVE it now that I've adjusted things. Super fun and entertaining successor to the original game. \n\n*Minor Spoiler*\n\nJust wanted knew players to be aware of this concern I had because the beginning of the game is heavy on combat tutorials. So even though it was guiding me how to play, it doesn't change the ease by which you can actually play. This detracted from my ability to fully dive into the introductory plot. Something that I definitely think the company should attempt to update in the future or at least learn from for future games.",

        "author": "98e8e72c-2dbe-540f-ad4f-be53c7a5139a",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 1193,
        "content": "[h1]-Overall Opinion-[/h1]\n\nThis is genuine Persona DNA through and through, even though the combat system is different. If you go in with an open mind you'll be pleasantly surprised with what they've done here. While it won't have a great level of tactical depth as a turn based Persona game, stringing combos together, pausing the action for a moment to bring out your persona and use an ability, it's all very seamless and well done. I'm enjoying the game so far, it really is a bonafide Persona 5 sequel (not Persona 5 Royal sequel). \n\n[h1]-Story-[/h1]\nI am 18 hours in so this is an initial impression. The premise here is fine, we are basically moving themes from corrupt adults doing whatever they want to fulfill their own selfish desire to social media being a bad influence on young adults and making them do awful things to get over their complex and escape the judgement of their peers. Perhaps at the end of this there will be an in-depth commentary on the effect of social media on our collective psyche. It is serviceable enough in retaining attention, however, without going into explicit spoilers, I do find the recycling of some of the motives that compel the phantom thieves to do what they do to be frustrating. \n\n[h1]-Graphics-[/h1]\n[olist]\n    [*]Very Stylized \u2705\n    [*]Supports up to 4K \u2705\n    [*]Borderless, full-screen, windowed options \u2705\n    [*]Some text does not scale well at high resolutions \u274c\n    [*]Limited graphical options (bloom, motion blur, AA, AO, textures, shadows) \u274c\n[/olist]\n\n[h1]-Performance-[/h1]\n[olist]\n    [*]Runs smooth \u2705\n    [*]Potato friendly \u2705\n    [*]Coin toss on if you'll play 4 hours without a single crash or one hour and crash 2 times. Patch needed.\u274c\n[/olist]\n\n[h1]-Misc-[/h1]\n[olist]\n    [*]Can be played with Keyboard and Mouse \u2705\n    [*]Supports key rebinding for KBM \u2705\n    [*]Soundtrack is absolute \ud83d\udd25\ud83d\udd25\ud83d\udd25\n[/olist]",

Gameplay is different than the original, but fun.\nAlso it's a bit more action oriented. Plus you do not need to bond with your friends like you had to in the first game. I personally would have had more fun if it was more like P5/P5R, but I would lie, if I say I don't like it.\n\nGreat game.\n\nPS: Hope I will find P5/P5R on Steam as well someday.",
        "comments": 0,
        "source": "steam",

    {
        "id": "87293675",
        "author": "928fe43c-8eec-56c5-8d68-447e7de8835b",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 8699,
        "content": "After 36 hours in I can safely say that this is not the Persona 5 experience I was hoping to get. The best thing about Persona 5 was how it blended together two different genres in one - JRPG and school simulator. Here you only have one genre - hack and slash with a little bit of RPG thrown in. This means that most of the time you will be doing the same things and that is it. And if you are not into the story, you will be left burned out from the experience. \n\nOn the plus side I was pleasantly surprised that the iconic style of Persona 5 has been implemented into the new gameplay and locations. Also, the story is captivating and imaginative like in the past instalments and I do love the road-trip-in-the-summer vibe. The characters stay true to themselves and there are plenty of funny and touching moments with them. Not surprisingly the music is a blast and I do like that through DLC you may get the remastered versions of the previous games' battle music to play during the combat. Finally, the addition of cooking was a nice touch as well. Yes, there is sort of a cooking mechanic in the original P5, but here you need to first unlock the meal through a recipe, which can be collected in various ways, and then you need to gather the needed materials to prepare the meal as well.  \n\nWhere Persona 5 Strikers disappoints is in the core gameplay, environments and playability. While interesting at first, the hack-and-slash quickly becomes boring and predictable, even if it uses the weakness and Persona systems from P5. I prefer the turn-based combat as there the gameplay did not feel the same even after 100 hours in. You got the negotiations, the all-out-attacks and ambushes were more meaningful, the single vs all spells were more distinctive from one another, which Persona you had with you was more crucial. Here the gameplay practically boils down to casting spells, to which the enemies are weak, until you get to all-out-attack. Everything else has been simplified way too much. You can heal and restore SP via items at any time without any repercussions. Futaba tells you the weakness of the enemy in the beginning of the fight - bosses as well. You do not need to take down every single enemy to trigger an all-out-attack. Also, there was something terrifying and at the same special when you had to face off several enemies at once in the original P5. Here, because there are literally hordes of enemies sometimes you won't even notice some of them and they will soon all blend in together. \n\nThe jails, themselves, have kept the unique environments from Persona 5 and they are not simply hallways. However, the feeling is the same as the one in Persona 4 - you go to a jail, do the same thing and end up in the same spot over and over again. There are no intricate puzzles, no surprise roadblocks or challenges. The formula is so far the same and thus, the locations feel the same, even if they are unique in their environments. The locations are also not exempt from this - sure, you will see plenty of Japanese cities, but essentially what you are getting per city are two mini locations filled with the same convenience stores and vending machines. Also, you can not do any extra activities in the cities - it is all just roaming the same street several times, buying several items and then going back to the Jail. Sure, occasionally if you talk to a member of the Phantom Thieves they might give you a side quest, which involves more than simply going up and down the map. However, the quests, themselves, are nothing that special and the missed opportunity to have a different version of a mini-game in each city is surely missing. \n\nFinally, while I said that there are plenty of character moments you are not involved with the characters that much, apart from the main story. One of the strongest aspects of Persona 5 were the interactions you had with the Phantom Thieves and the confidants, which happened outside of the main narrative. In Persona 5 Strikers you only get some boring side quests (like I mentioned) and some lines regarding the city / the particular moment in the story. \n\nI feel like I would be in the minority of people, who expected more of the game and were left disappointed, but I had to write this review down for anybody like me, who felt in love in Persona 5 and were eagerly anticipating this game. And can you blame me - they made Persona 5 Strikers look like it is a sequel to Persona 5. Apart from the story, it is anything but a sequel. \n\n",

        "content": "Rollin back in here, still not done but hot damn this game does not stop. Does it slow down when it needs to? Yes.That said, I keep waiting for this game to become formulaic like its predecessor and it seems to be made specifically to prevent the player from getting complacent. Sure, there's a degree of predictability, but for the most part, it's a fun and unpredictable ride. \n\nWhat I've played of this combined with my experience with Astral Chain leads me to believe that, if Omega Force let themselves out of their own cage more often, they would easily outpace Platinum at their own strengths. Each game of theirs I've played since Dynasty Warriors 8 has begun to diverge further and further from the formula they used to strictly employ and it is completely for the better. Hyrule Warriors: Calamity was pretty good, but...I don't know if Atlus really knew how to draw their potential out of them or if they just were encouraged to just let loose and go wild but holy crap the gameplay feels great.\n\nCouple that with the soundtrack, which the mediocre tracks in this outpace some of the best tracks in the already stellar soundtrack Persona 5 had and you have a mixture for a game that frequently just hits the damn zenith for what an action game can make the player feel.\n\nAll that said, the game doesn't forget the series it's in. Many have said it's a love letter to fans of the series and it feels exactly like that. The plot builds on the characters they spent over 100 hours feeding us backstory and introducing to us, and Strikers serves to just show us how all of them have grown, both individually and as a group of friends who haven't seen each other for a year, but still kept in touch.\n\nI could honestly go on longer but I think the point is made, and I'd rather not spoil anything.",

        "content": "TDLR; Very fun gameplay but has only a decent story that gets the job done, has tedious grinding, and some pc port issues. \n\n\nBefore I start there're a few things I'd like to note. PLEASE for the love of god wait for a patch. Now that I've been playing for longer the more and more issues I've been having with the pc version. It crashes often, leading me to lose progress, I've lost around 4 hours of progress in total which has been extremely infuriating. [b][EDIT: This issue has been resolved in the latest beta hotfix][/b]Performance has had dips, while not constant they're noticeable. The settings that come with the game do almost nothing, so i had to go into Nvidia control panel to make AA myself. At this point I cannot progress through one of the last jails because of a loading screen that makes my game crash each time. I do recommend the actual game but don't buy right now, will edit if there is a fix. \n\nHere's the actual review:\n\nWow ok I am pleasantly surprised by this game. At first I was worried about it being another generic warriors game but I looked into the game more and it looked more like a Persona game than warriors which is the case. So if you're worried about that, don't be. I've also been surprised of how big the jails are, you can run around them freely for the most part except from a few linear sections and minor puzzles.\n\nThe combat is so fluid. It incorporates almost all elements of Persona 5 in one way or another. You can pause time and use specials to hit an enemies weakness and then all out attack is just as satisfying as it was in Persona 5, whilst not as flashy.  Baton passes, 1 mores, buffs/debuffs, futaba support all make their way into the game as well. Fusing personas and using them in battle is still in the game, but not as expanded, which is fine and I only noticed a few times after forgetting. You can blast through the game for a lot of it but with minimal effort except the boss fights, the difficulty scaling is a little whacky. \n\nThe story is worse than Persona 5 but it does have its charm. The story feels like a copy and paste for the first 2 jails but kind of picks up around the fourth jail, which I'm glad it did. The layout of the first two jails also feel similar which i'm confused by since they are supposed to be different. For what the story is overall, it's decent enough to warrant another journey with the phantom thieves.\n\nSome misc. gripes I have with the game is that you never have enough SP so SP items are essential though they're hard to get in large quantity, but you can leave and re enter the jail with no penalty. The grinding in this game is so unnecessarily shitty for late game personas, it requires much lower level personas to reach a threshold in level before you fuse them. How do you level them up? Persona Points which are given in low quantities and increase the amount needed to level up a persona each time, this made completing the registry worse than in vanilla Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal. Camera can also be whacky but isn't a huge deal.\n\nIf I had to rate the game I'd give it a 8/10.",

        "content": "You know how that period in Persona 5 where you finished Egypt Palace, you got summer cutscene, funny interaction between the party, the Hawai school trip and everything's bright and nice ? That's Persona 5 Striker but Haru's here and you're off to a roadtrip.\n\nGameplaywise it's looks like a musou and standard attacks are musou like, however it plays more like an action RPG in the same vein as the FF7 remake, if not faster and more busy on screen.\n\nTrash mob is trash so you can musou however you want, instead the big meat is on mini-boss and boss fight where your standard musou square-triangle combo will never work because you'll get hit before finishing it,\n\nIn those case you'll go back to the gameplay of a Megaten game, where you'll use buff and debuffs (r), hit weakness using persona and keep yourself healed, all of this to break shields and initiate an all out attacks.\n\nHowever this time, unlike the turn base of a Megaten/Persona, you'll be actively dodging the boss attack in the arena while switching characters and using special moves granted by environmental objects.\n\nKeep in mind that's it's a full sequel to P5 (it doesn't explicitly show everything about P5 plot/endgame but you are expected to know the characters, their background,personality etc, so yeah it's not a point of entry game) , loading are a bit long even on SSD, and there's some weird issues with anti aliasing that makes the text ugly (removing it fixes that but the characters models in the menu will have jagged edges, it's totally fine in gameplay tho)\n\n",

    {
        "id": "87287649",
        "author": "bc8a98bb-6131-5567-bd50-d38e64f7f77a",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 2578,
        "content": "Sequels don't work, at least most of the time. Spin-offs are bad, at least as a general rule. And then, along came Persona 5 Strikers, which serves as much of a spin-off as a sequel. It is by no means a perfect game, no game is perfect, but this is goddam near it. Atlus could have re-skinned a warriors game whit Persona, and i would have bought it. Instead, what i got was a love letter to both, the Phantom Thieves and the Players. \n\nThis carries over a great deal of Persona 5. While some elements are shaved due to mechanics, most of them evolved with the gameplay change. Confidants are replaced by a bond system, you generate bond points trough certain requests or by fighting along characters. As expected the buffs from bonds are geared towards action games, more damage, faster bond growth, etc. At the same time this serves as a much friendlier system to the player, while still advances the narrative and deepens the bond between characters with the random personal request.\nAll the over the top action and showtimes are still present, and i must say, they are one of my favorite animations from the game, Atlus really brought out the personality of each Phantom Thieve trough this silly little animations. The combat itself feels fluid and gratifying, if at times a bit repetitive killing random trash. But where the game really shines is trough their boss fights. This has one of my favorite Boss encounters of the saga, and i thought it was nearly impossible to beat Futaba's Palace Boss. It could still use a bit more information on screen, like the direction and the type of incoming attacks from outside the screen, but it is by no means a deal breaker.\n\nThe downside to this game is, if you have not played Persona 5 OG you will probably feel left out on most of the conversations. A lot of references and inside jokes are beautiful winks to veterans of the saga, but might flew over the head of those not familiar with the lore, and i must say, this might lower your enjoyment of the game.\n\nOverall i will say, give this game a change if you are a fan of Persona 5, if you haven't played Persona 5 yet, i will still recommend buying this one, as it is a very good warriors like game, and despite the random reference you might miss, the game does a very good job at exploring the characters and the narrative is A+ as i have come to expect from Atlus.\n\nPros\n\n++Combat is fluid and rewarding\n++Graphics are BEAUTIFUL\n++4k 60fps\n++Controls are very good and have a variety of schemes\n++More P5 and Phantom Thieves\n++Story Rich as any other Persona/Shin Megami\n\nCons\n\n--Heavy loaded with references and inside jokes (not necessary to enjoy the game, but you do miss some of the enjoyment)\n--No TIa Takemi ( SRSLY NGGS where is ma TIA)\n--Somewhat short (about 40-50ish hours depending on how fast you rush it)\n--No costumes DLC (yes for this game, that is a Con, trust me on this one)\n\nAll in all, if you are a P5 fan this is a 9/10, if you are not, this is easy an 8/10. Buy it now!!",
        "comments": 0,
        "source": "steam",
        "helpful": 1,
        "funny": 0,
        "recommended": true,
        "franchise": "Persona",
        "gameName": "Persona 5 Strikers"

Most systems from Persona series are coming back and fit in really nicely (Elemental weakness, One-more, All-out-attack, Showtime.) It feels not out of place and keep it very true to the lore of Persona 5 in every aspect from gameplay, design, theme, and world's logic.\n\nOne thing that can be see as a downside is P5S is the direct continuation of Persona 5 (with some references to P5R too.) And it's not a small side story but pretty much a full fledged saga. Not really. But your reaction would be \"Oh! I remember that! Nice!\" every thirty seconds to \"WTF just happened?\" based on your exposure to Persona franchise.         "content": "Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5 (You kinda have to ignore the new additions of P5R, sorry Kasumi!)\nStorywise the game is so good and actually surprised me since I didn't expect a good story at all! \nBut I don't want to talk a single thing about the story even if they won't be considered as spoilers because it's the best if you enter the game blindly! But also the game needs the player to know one thing and another about the phantom thieves, some other characters, persona aspects, etc. It's not 100% necessary tho but trust me you can't understand/enjoy much of the story if it is your first ever persona game! \nMany people think that Persona 5 strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game with a persona theme but nope, it's much more like a real-time action Jrpg than that.\nThe combat system is not turn-based anymore,instead it features real-time combo based combat which is a new&cool experience IMO. For me the combat was starting to get boring and smash button like in the first jail of the game but then I changed the difficulty to hard and also the game introduced more challenging enemies, so if you don't want to feel the same play on high or at least medium difficulty and also don't ignore dire shadows.\nThe combat is pretty enjoyable and a nice addition to the old turn-based combat system.\nMany main factors of P5 or persona series in general are removed or been cut down in Persona 5 strikers such as Velvet room, Social links, daily calender system, and many other stuff that are all simplified/removed. \nOverall, P5 strikers is a must play for P5 fans who couldn't wait to see phantom thieves again! but if you haven't played P5 yet or even any other persona games and also if you can't get along with the new simplified aspects of the game,then you should probably ignore the game/wait for sales.\n\nNow please keep bringing persona games to steam Atlus ! \n\nP4 Spoiler P.S: [spoiler] Adachi is the best striker!     {
        "id": "87284099",
        "author": "b29c4f9d-c10c-5d77-a146-0ffa4b9b5ba7",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 4895,
        "content": "Persona 5 Strikers is probably the best \"Warriors\" game ever made.\n---\nYou play as Joker, a person with the Wild Card ability, which is a pass for using multiple Personas in the franchise. You and Morgana returned to Tokyo for your summer vacation, after planning for a barbecue with your friends, you were suddenly thrown into the Metaverse once more...\n---\n[h1]Combat[/h1]\nThe combat is a combination of both Warriors-series by Omega Force and Persona-series, although it's a lot more similar to \"Devil Summoner 2: Raidou Kuzunoha vs. King Abaddon\", with the fluidity and mobility of \"Warriors\" combat. You'll still primarily press a series of buttons to execute your attacks and strong attacks, however, you can also pause in-combat to use your Persona skills or recovery items.\nEach character, Persona, and enemy have their own kit, strength, and weaknesses. The way abilities are used by enemies will vary for each type of enemy, for example, Mara's \"One-Shot Kill\" would send a barrage of bullets towards the enemy (and 'stains' you for some reason), while Seth's \"One Shot Kill\" would be an explosion. This variation makes for a unique encounter for each enemy. You can obtain Personas by defeating them in the battlefield, or by fusing two (or more) Personas in the Velvet Room.\nThe hack-and-slash gameplay is vastly different than in other Warriors games. Each enemy will also have a \"Knockdown Gauge\" which, if depleted, will knock them down and enables \"1 More\" move and/or \"All-Out Attack\" for the player. You can deplete the gauge by dealing critical hits or striking the enemies' weaknesses. If the enemy still has \"Knockdown Gauge\", they won't stagger at all by your normal attacks, which lets them to counter your attacks by using abilities.\nYou can play as one of four characters that you choose before delving into a dungeon. Each character is actually fun to play, and each of them has certain characteristics in their movesets which are unique to them, which makes for a fun, different playstyle for each character -- something that is missing from modern Warriors games.\n-----\n[h1]Story[/h1]\nAh, the story. Before the story starts, there was an phenomenon called the \"Change of Hearts\" epidemic in which some high-profile figures confessed to many scandals, the authorities ruled out the possibility that the Phantom Thieves are the perpetrator behind this phenomenon and started an investigation against them.\nBack to Joker and friends. After planning for a barbecue, they downloaded an app called EMMA, an artificial intelligence guide, which also doubles as an SNS app in which users can become friends with each other by sharing their \"keywords\". Turns out, some keywords will send people's Shadows to Jails within the Metaverse. With the Metaverse's return, Joker and the Phantom Thieves set out to solve the mystery behind it. Along the way, they were informed by a member of the authorities that the same phenomenon is currently happening in Sapporo, and the said member also asked the assistance of the Phantom Thieves to solve the case.\nThe Phantom Thieves decided that they would spend their summer vacation solving the mystery of the Jails and the Metaverse, while also having a road trip across various cities in Japan.\n---\nThe story is a generic slice-of-life anime story with a pinch of \"Shin Megami Tensei\", typical Persona games. The 3D cutscenes and incredible voice acting makes the story interesting enough for me, that I can endure a 40 minute-long series of cutscenes.\nBottom line, the story is pretty good, but the duration of the cutscenes are probably too long for some people.\n-----\n[h1]Difficulty[/h1]\nIf you played both Warriors and Persona games, then you'll want to cross Easy and Normal out of your choices. Hard difficulty offers a tough but fair combat, and you'll risk of actually losing the battle.\nAfter you beat the game and beat the ultimate boss, you'll unlock a new difficulty for New Game+ called \"Merciless\". This difficulty will crank enemy status through the roof, even early Shadows like Pixies and Jack o' Lanterns will easily kill you. Hell, the tutorial Bicorn feels like Chaos-Lu Bu where you can be killed in two hits -- even if you're level 82 with high-tier Personas.\nSo yeah, go with Hard mode for the first playthrough, and choose Merciless for the second playthrough. At least you won't be too surprised by the difficulty jump in New Game+.\n-----\n[h1]Cons[/h1]\nCrashes. I experienced more than 12 crashes in my first playthrough, it often happens after leaving the Velvet Room, whenever cutscene background changing drastically (for example, from inside LeBlanc to outside LeBlanc), and leaving dungeons. Some even happen in the middle of a series of cutscenes after a 10 minutes boss fight. I really hope that this doesn't happen to anyone else.\n------\n[h1]Conclusion[/h1]\nI had fun playing this game, 54 hours of hack-and-slash-plus-JRPG fun accompanied by an interesting and entertaining story -- makes for a game I would easily recommend to anyone. I hope that I can see another Strikers game again from Atlus and Omega Force.\n-----\nThat being said, please port Persona 5 Royal to PC, Atlus.",

        "content": "The unexpected persona game to say the least but ATLUS did a very good job of keeping this game, well... still in the theme of Persona.\n\n[h1] Combat Mechanics [/h1]\nTo be simple, Turn-based JRPG turn Real-Time.\nA lot combat aspects are still there, surprisingly. Exploit weaknesses, All-Out-Attack, Baton Pass.[b] THEY ARE ALL STILL THERE! [/b] I'm surprise of how they are manage to do that and make it work flawlessly. And the most exciting of all, the Showtime is just gorgeous!\n\n[h1] Everyday Mechanics [/h1]\nApart from the cut confidant, not a lot have change. You start by gather the information about the target  and then you go in the dungeon now call \"The Jail\" and then you go to a total nut job mode. Sometime do a request and spend time talking with teammates or inside the RV. Basically the game loop is that.\nBond system is the new one that they introduce in this game. Similar to Social Links/Confidant but instead of going to each teammates and get their abilities, you get points to upgrades which you will need them.\n\n[h1] Story [/h1]\nSince currently at the time of this review I have not finish the game yet and I know that no ones want a spoiler. So the only thing that I'm going to talking about is how they tell the story.\nThe story goes on like in the Persona 5, you notice that something is going on in Shibuya just when the Thieves are having a summer trip and later they know that the issue is going across the japan in various cities. The story has to deal with trauma of \"the Monarch\", the ruler of Jail, that works like a Palace [b]with a twist[/b].\n\n[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]\nTalk about Persona without the music is [b]WRONG[/b].\nAlthough Shoji Meguro, ATLUS house composer, is not the composer in Persona 5 Striker, the music still an absolute banger! Sound effects overall is perfect.\nRight now I really dig \"Welcome To The Jail\", \"Counter Strike\", \"Axe To Grind\", \"You are Stronger\" and a lot more!\n\nTo be honest, the things that ATLUS did. This would be a bottom at my list of what ATLUS would do the their games and I have doubt at first about this being the Beat'em Up kind of game because I don't like this kind of game. But they really take my breath away here, got to give it to them.\n\n[h1]Some After Thought[/h1]\nWhat I said above is all true, this game is still a fantastic game and I urge anyone who interested in this game to play. HOWEVER, this game-by all means-still is not a traditional Persona experience. I still recommend mainline Persona more than this game overall. And since this is a beat 'em up game and this is a linear-story game, the replay-ability is next to none apart from the completionist gamer. So for me, the flaws of this game is really \"It's not normal Persona\" which is dumb. ATLUS did a thing that throw us off, and they done a fantastic job. The bitter opening of this paragraph will not effect my verdict.\n\nThis. is. still. fantastic.",

        "content": "Absolute brilliant game. If you have played and enjoyed Persona 5 you will want to play this. The combat does for Persona what FF7 Remake does for FF7.\n\nThe game is not without it's technical bugs which will hopefully be ironed out. I was more than willing to overlook these issues and power through as the game is just really good and hard to put down.\n\nIf you haven't played Persona 5 However I would recommend holding off on playing this until you have.     {
        "id": "87282114",
        "author": "1d288d83-6414-5a36-b007-a674401c54b5",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 2982,
        "content": "TLDR : A Refreshing take on the Persona franchise that actually works pretty well, with a few hiccups here and there. A solid game despite the lack of it's predecessor, P5 being on Steam (GIVE US P5R ON PC ATLUS / SEGA!) \n\nFull Review :\n\nPersona 5 Strikers takes the traditional turn based combat gameplay of Persona and actually manages to make a pretty good hack'n'slash adaptation of it. Persona skills and all work well within a real-time environment, and you even have the ability to string them into combos for no SP cost too (SP is basically the \"mana\" of Persona, for the newcomers). \n\nThe game does have one major flaw though in it's execution, the lack of the social aspect of Persona. In the mainline Modern Persona games (Persona 3 FES / P3 Portable / Persona 4 Golden (it's on Steam too go buy it) / Persona 5 / P5R) you have a big focus on the social side of gameplay, interacting with your companions, potential romance options, etc., which tie into the dungeon crawling aspect of them by strengthening companions you have strong bonds too. None of that is present in Strikers here, which is a shame. \n\nStrikers is also much more linear than the mainline games. That's not to say the mainline games I'm comparing it too had multiple endings or anything (P4 had like 7, P5R had 4 or so if I remember right), but they had a TON of stuff mixed into the social side, such as choosing whether to go out with friends (strengthen bonds) or do something to strengthen your own stats on a specific day. Speaking of days, in Strikers there isn't any time progression outside of story events, so unlike in the main games, there's nothing really pressuring you to pick and choose things, so you can basically just sit and grind if you want, which, admittedly works well for Strikers gameplay wise, but still worth noting the difference there. \n\nThe game also lacks a lot of the Personas from 3-5 too, there's a lot, don't get me wrong, just MUCH more in the main games, though I'm not counting it as a negative thing, still plenty to choose from and you can easily use the Persona Points system (unique to Strikers, not in earlier games) and the accumulated power system to strengthen your favorite Personas. That plus the fusion system which is a Persona mainstay allow for you to easily take that level 5 weak Persona and turn him into a 99-Stat monster. \n\nThe dungeons are also different here as well, they're much more open than the ones in Persona 3, 4 and 5, while keeping the similar style that dungeons in Persona 5 had. This is mostly due to the combat being you and the Phantom Thieves against a horde of shadows every time, but it works. \n\nOverall it's pretty great. If you haven't played Persona 5 Royal (or the base Persona 5) you may be somewhat lost with the terms and world of the game, but outside of the story of the Phantom Thieves and the Metaverse, you can still have a good time and know the basics. The story isn't as good as the mainline games either, likely due to it being shorter and more condensed (40 hours in Strikers vs. 100 hours in Persona 4 Golden or 150 in P5 Royal). \n\nAlso, if you're wondering about the DLC under the game, ignore the All Out Attack Pack, but definitely go and buy the legacy BGM pack, as it includes battle themes from every mainline Persona games, even the old 1990s Persona 1 and 2 that nobody remembers. It also includes the very popular themes from P3, P3P, P4, and P4G, that is to say\n\n- A Lone Prayer (Persona 1)\n-Mass Destruction (Persona 3)\n-Wiping All Out (Persona 3 Portable, from the Female Main Character's Route in that game)\n- Reach out To the Truth (Persona 4)\n- Time to Make History (Persona 4 Golden) \n\nYou actually also get the themes from Persona 5  and Persona 5 Royal IN THE BASE GAME WITHOUT DLC, you just have to beat the main story and get a game cleared save file to get access to them, but the base game does come with a pretty awesome rock remix of Last Surprise (P5's theme) in the base game before then, it's pretty neat. \n\nI'd like to end this review by engaging in the time honored tradition of port-begging\n*ahem*\n\nPLEASE ATLUS / SEGA GIVE US PERSONA 3 FES and PERSONA 5 ROYAL!\n\nThank you for reading this review and I hope it helped.",

ATLUS and KT Games succeed in mixing the Dynasty warriors gameplay of their games with the quality of worldbuilding, strong characters, good writing and sharp art design of Persona 5.\nThe Gameplay is action heavy and not too complex but still somehow engaging and nice to look at.\nThe game completely lacks the life sim of Persona and makes the time of the game play out as you complete specific story events. You can expect dynasty warriors gameplay but with a Persona Twist as you are able to stop time and attack your opponent(s) with a wide variety of physical and magic moves, that have different types, just like in a Pokemon Game. This adds a leven of complexity to the gameplay and preparation (SP).\nThe Game features FANTASTIC MUSIC both new and from the Persona 5 game. Also it features the good UX design from P5.\nThe game runs well on my 3070 at 4k60 max settings and my friends report a good experience even on dated Hardware like the 1060, you can expect 1080p60 max settings with a solid bit of overhead here.\nThe only thing that is a bit of a mixed bag is the difficulty, there are some spikes that could have been balanced better, and the UX during fights. (sometimes there is just tooo much happening on screen to see what your character is doing)\nIf you didn't play Persona 5: THIS GAME CONTAINS SPOILERS for that game and the Story does not properly explain the core concepts of Persona, that you need in order to understand everything well!!\nAll in all Persona5 Scramble: The phantom Strikers is a good game, that hase some flaws but is a mostly enjoyable experience.\nYou schould absolutely play it if:\n- You played and enjoyed Persona 5 and you desperately want to immerse yourself in that world again.\n- You like Dynasty Warriors Gameplay and have a solid idea of what Persona is all about\nYopu should avoid it if:\n- You are looking for a straight up Persona 5 sequel with life sim and all, this game is not that\n- you want ultra deep and complex Gameplay that is easy to learn, hard to master\n- You have never played a Persona Game or don't know what persona even is\n\nFor me PERSONALLY tha game is a 7/10\n",

        "content": "Disclaimer: I can only recommend this game if you have already played Persona 5 (Base or Royal) because knowing the events beforehand is too important.\n\nThis game has all the level Persona 5 storytelling and the main cast that you probably enjoy. This game's twist is basically that it turns the traditional turn based Persona system into a stylish and dynamic real-time RPG with some hack-n-slash elements. Also this game is definitely quite easy until the ending where it gets somewhat challenging so I recommend to play on Hard which honestly feels kind of easy for someone new to the genre. Another gripe is that the game right now as a crashing issue and I see other people are experiencing it too - personally I have crashed like 7-8 times during my gameplay (usually when fast-travelling) so I HIGHLY recommend saving whenever you can until this issue is resolved. If you can look past these flaws, The story is solid, you'll get your values worth with ~40 hours of content, and the game is legitimately fun and addicting. \n\n8/10",

        "content": "The closest thing we'll get from Persona 5 on PC until Atlus ports the thing itself or (preferably) the Royal remake.\n\nOverall, the game is great. It is basically Persona 5-2, but with a complete change in gameplay. If you enjoyed the original game, this title is a must. I'd say this is an almost perfect adaptation from the turn-based style to a hack-and-slash type of game, keeping the same Shadows weaknesses, strengths and spells.\n\nHowever, it has its flaws. By the time I'm writing this review the game kept crashing randomly, either while loading a new in-game rendered cutscene (which can make you lose quite a bit of progress in the first dungeons) or when entering a Jail. The Anti-Aliasing messes with the text a bit (not something that makes the game unplayable, but it feels a bit weird). \n\nThe Keyboard and Mouse Button Configuration is also severely lacking. It's not as bad as only having preset controls like Mega Man Zero/ZX Legacy Collection, but anything to the right of \"Enter\" is unbindable, which means anyone who uses the Arrow Keys will have a really hard time playing unless they have a controller.\n\nBut still, the game is awesome and well worth of being a sequel to Persona 5.",

        "id": "87276362",
        "author": "479975cb-d73b-5099-bdf2-254e26f2247b",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 3701,
        "content": "Persona 5 Strikers certainly is a worthy successor to Atlus' 2017/2020 masterpiece.\n\nThe Phantom Thieves' sequel story was a joy the whole way through, and I'm incredibly happy to have been apart for it.  The writing is on par with the original and Royal, and while this game is more of a \"fan service-y\" type deal, Atlus made sure to not forget about what made Persona 5 great in the first place, creating a fun road trip adventure that didn't need to be told, but I'm glad it was. Seeing the thieves older and wiser while also keeping their charm and traits from the original mad me smile, and allowed me to truly see just how much these characters have grown. \n\nThe Musou style combat mixed in with Persona turn based elements came together perfectly, and while the camera can be a but weird sometimes, the combat always remained fluid and fun and never got boring even until the very end of the game. Persona fusion also makes a return, and while I have my quarrels with the new PP system, Persona Fusion is still crazy fun to do, allowing the player to create some incredibly OP Persona's that just shred enemies to a fine shadow-y paste. \n\nI became a huge Persona fan after playing Royal back in August. I never really was a JRPG guy, but for some reason Persona 5 always peaked my interest, and when I finally played it I fell in love. The Phantom Thieves are probably my favorite cast of video game characters period, and after 6 months of playing through the entire franchise, I was incredibly happy to be with the thieves on another adventure. I just hope this isn't their last.",

While the problems of the story still going way too fast for my liking is still there i enjoyed that it actually finally felt like the phantom thieves were actual friends and the dynamic they have in this game is miles better than in the original game. The gameplay itself is a little bit rough around the edges and the 2d platforming parts are especially clunky, but besides that the gameplay is solid and fun. also being able to randomly play the battle themes from the previous games is the coolest thing ever, and it can lead to some pretty cool moments with the song matching up with the actions you are doing in the game.     {
        "id": "87273803",
        "author": "9d13bb95-1344-5651-9a6a-167c390f3830",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 3705,
        "content": "Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic follow-up to Persona 5, all the while discarding the modern Persona combat in favor of a musuo experience. Fundamentally, modern Persona is defined by its balance between the RPG dungeon crawling and the life sim, tying them together with a calendar. This game removes the time constraints, making the calendar mere decoration. Moreover, social links/confidants are replaced with the Bond system, giving players access to a variety of perks of their choosing. The fusion system itself has also been greatly simplified. With all of this in mind, it seems as though this game throws out everything that made its predecessors special. However, this game gains more focus on narrative as a result of this. Many fun character interactions stem from this focus and smaller cast. It allows the game to take a form all its own, rather than being more of the same. And all the more, the battles still feel very Persona-esque thanks to ailments, follow-ups, baton passes, weakness, technicals, All-Out Attacks, Persona-switching, and more. I can't recommend this if you don't like action games. But if you even have a minor interest and you played the original/Royal Persona 5, then I heavily recommend this game. Also, the baton pass is literally a high five button now and I love it.",

        "hours": 7604,
        "content": "First of all, this game is a sequel of Persona 5. Since Persona 5 is a complete game of its own, there are no major plot points that you need to know to play the game. However, you need to know the major characters from Persona 5 to be able to enjoy Persona 5 Strikers. If you have not watched or played Persona 5, please at least read the wiki pages on all the playable characters.\n\nSecond, the combat changes drastically from Persona 5 (turn-based RPG) to hack-and-slash (specifically Warrior/Musou style aka the Omega-Force style). Check out the gameplay video if you don't know what this means. Most other major Persona gameplay mechanics remain the same (protag wild card personas, level up, etc).\n\nIf you've read up to here and you're okay with everything I've said so far, this is THE GAME for you. \n\nThis game is basically everything you love about Persona 5 on steroid. This game sets during the Summer right after Persona 5 ended. You'd get to see how characters you loved from Persona 5 grow, how they use what they've learned to help people as the Phantom Thieves. One thing that I think Persona 4 did better than Persona 5 is the character development, but Persona 5 Strikers easily outrank Persona 4 on this front (partially because all characters are available and interacting since the beginning of the game).",

        "author": "225f7b2e-b086-544a-bd68-7c5464d89ae6",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 4405,
        "content": "Save OFTEN, because the game will randomly crash for absolutely no reason. I've lost quite a bit of progress because of this.\n\nPretty good game, a decent sequel to Persona 5. It's a shame it doesn't include references or callbacks to Royal, but that's okay. \n\nThe UI is a bit too large, but you get used to it quickly. \n\nThe combat feels pretty good overall, but early on it's quite difficult, even on normal difficulty. \nYou can and probably will die almost instantly. \nIf you happen to get trapped in between a Shadow and a wall or hit with a debuff in the early areas of the game you'll most likely lose that character until the fight is over. It's honestly quite punishing and a bit frustrating at times. \n\nOnce you level up a bit and start getting bond skills to increase your health and MP it gets somewhat easier but it always seems like enemies hit a lot harder than you're expecting until you're several levels higher than they are.\n\nMaybe save the \"Hard\" difficulty playthrough for NG+.\n\nVoice acting, soundtrack, and sound design are all great. \nAll the playable characters feel unique and are very fun to use.\nOverall a very solid musou style game. Glad I purchased it. \n\nYou technically don't need to play Persona 5/Royal to understand this story, but they reference it enough where it will severely detract from the experience if you haven't played at least one of those games. \n\nThat being said; Atlus PLEASE port Persona 5 Royal to Steam, I'm glad we at least get the sequel but it feels wrong to not have the previous installment yet.         "hours": 6459,
        "content": "SPOILER FREE\n\nPersona 5 Strikers is a great game, a must play if you've played Persona 5 or Royal. Note that this is a sequel to 5, not Royal, so characters like Kasumi, and Maruki won't be in here. The story so far is great, but I did notice that there are moments where we get explained concepts that we already know, so I guess if you haven't played Persona 5 or Royal you could jump in, but you would be spoiled character outcomes and stuff like that. I expected the story to be less quality since it isn't as long as 5, but it's actually great. I'm invested into the story an the characters once again. The game runs great on PC, and it looks very nice (I played P5 on the PS3 so that's why it looks so good to me). There is original music, and there are remixes. The music is great. Nitpicks are that anti aliasing is noticeable and I would play with a controller. I have never played a Warriors game, and my friends that have tell me that it gets boring at some point. For me, its my first time so I'm having a lot of fun. I like the mix between Persona and Warriors. One mores, all outs, technicals, they all return. I've played about 25 hours, and I'm having a lot of fun. Definite recommend. If you pick it up, enjoy!",

        "id": "87272386",
        "author": "82f01323-b9b9-59aa-b7a6-bee609e1aac3",
        "date": "23-02-21",
        "hours": 2978,
        "content": "*SPOILER FREE*\nPersona 5 x Warriors series seems like an idea that shouldn't work but somehow it pulls it off amazingly\n\nThere have been multiple times I've genuinely forgot that this was not actually a regular persona game, running about the city talking to everyone, the interactions between characters, the cutscenes and music all just felt so natural. Even the combat itself doesn't feel out of place and seamlessly flows in and out whenever fights start.\n\nThis game has all the elements of persona 5 woven into it in an interesting way, things like baton passes, follow up attacks, persona fusing and all out attacks are still here but made to fit the hack and slash gameplay of a warriors game.\nThe difficulty is actually decent for one of these type games too, usually you just mindlessly mash buttons and feel good taking out thousands at a time but here there are fewer enemies on screen and a harder fight overall, the bosses themselves are also unique and are much more challenging than anything found in its similar titles.\n\nThe music to this game shattered my expectations, I assumed it would be good already seeing as both of the franchises have amazing music already but they really outdid themselves. I got the legacy music pack expecting to flick to that but so far i haven't even wanted to incase i missed out on any of the incredible new tracks.\n\nThe DLC for this game in terms of items is definitely skippable, it honestly doesn't do much at all and so far I haven't used any of it myself. The persona level up points may come in handy eventually but the skills haven't really been necessary, they already give you tons and if you have played a persona game before then you already know how to fuse your way to victory.\n\nThe story takes place after regular Persona 5 and not Royal. As such some players of the newer version may notice differences in character portraits or persona passives in fusing. The new character from royal also doesn't make an appearance but there are plenty more new faces added regardless\n\nThe only real gripe I have is that the game looks similar to the ps3 version of P5 and the text is a little off putting at first. I eventually got used to it but I wish there were options to make it look a bit smoother. Other than that it runs fine during gameplay with the occasional crash which can be annoying though it throws so many opportunities to save at you that the most progress I lost was 1 cutscene that i skipped upon reloading anyway.\n\nOverall I'd say this is the most amount of effort of any Koei-Tecmo mainline or spin-off game and even people who don't like their usual stuff should give this one a shot. If you are a fan of persona 5 then you really don't want to miss out on this.",
